BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 10, 1922
THE STUDENT ACTIVITIES COUNCIL'S REPORT

In this issue of the NEWS-LETTER
we are publishing the report of the
Student Activities Council for the
months of October, November and
December. Lack of space, unfortunately, prevents us from publishing a more detailed report, but from
all accounts the advantages of having such a council is unquestionable. The accounts are in excellent
shape and are accurately kept
through the centralized form of
bookkeeping adopted. Bills are
promptly paid, and a check is kept
on each activity, which prevents it
from exceeding its budget. The
'only activity in difficulty at present
is the Blue Jay, which had a deficit
of some three hundred and fifty
dollars from last year to meet this
fall. It is thought, however, that
with economy and hard work it
will be possible to make up this deficit by next year. The deficit last
February was over five hundred
dollars, two hundred of which was
made up in the last two issues of
last spring. Other activities which

THE SWIMMING TEAM

The Swimming Team needs $90,
to carry out its season, and it has
asked the students to support them
to that extent. Instead of asking
for contributions at a mass-meeting, however, it has planned a
dance to be given after its principal meet. We do not believe that
there is any danger of the students
failing to furnish the required support. The tickets are on sale now.
"Cotne early and avoid the rush !"

Approaches.
Lehigh
Pending.

ATHLETIC GOSSIP

Meet

Tickets have been placed on sale
for the swimming meet to be held
with Lehigh at the B. A. C. pool
on February 11. The contract for
this meet is being held up until
enough tickets are disposed of to
assure the payment of the guarantee to Lehigh. The future of the
swimming team depends upon the
disposal of these tickets. If Hopkins fails to meet Lehigh, who is
a member of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming Association,
Hopkins will probably be dropped
ftom the league. The meet will
be followed by an informal dance.
Tickets 'are $1.50 per couple or $1
a person, and may be procured from
Andy, Landy & Co. or from members of the team.
The swimmers took their first
plunge of the season at the B. A. C.
pool last Wednesday. Only members of last year's team and Freshmen with previous experience were
told to report owing to limited facilities.

Men wishing to try for the team
will be given trials within the next
two weeks. The first meet is scheduled on January 21, at Swarthmore, and Manager Rowland and
Captain Buhrer, in charge of the
swimmers, will be forced to put the
men through daily practices in orcarried over a deficiency from last
year were the Dramatic Club and der to get them in condition at such
an early date. An unusually diffithe Debating Council.

large proportion of the students
have paid the fee, and are especially glad to hear that many who ai-e
not legally required to pay it have
done so in order to take advantage
ef the reduced rates. We only hope
thg the balance will pay as soon as
possible, not only for the advantages which they receive, but in order that the activities will receive
the unanimous support of the students.

The proposed football game with
the University of Maryland, according to unofficial information,
is about as far from a reality as it
was this time last year. The matter is at present being considered
by President Goodnow.
Lacrosse seems to be going
strong at all the big Eastern universities. Syracuse has made it a
major sport and Princeton has officially recognized it as a minor
sport. We are trying to get a game
with Princeton on June 3, and although the contracts are not signed
it looks as though we will have the
chance to entertain them on that
date.
Boxing apparently has gotten a
good hold at Hopkins. "Doc"
Rhodes is giving instruction to the
embryo battlers three evenings a
week at Homewood Field. Candidates for the team also get in some
good licks during vacant periods
in the students' room of the M. E.
Building.

and a well-balanced team is necessary in order to complete it with
satisfactory results. Captain Buhrer, Manager Rowland, Hall, Johnston, Morrell,

Hambleton

and

Coady of last year's team remain
as a nucleus.

Some of the new

candidates are showing up well and
are expected to make strong bids
for places on the team.

FIRST COTILLON OF YEAR HUGE
SUCCESS

The first cotillon of the collegiate year was held in the C. E. Hall
on Wednesday night, December 21,
1921. The dancing began at 9.00
P. M. to the jazzy strains of Lou
Fisher's orchestra. The chaperons
in attendance were Dr. and Airs.
John H. Latane, Dr. and Mrs. J.
B. Whitehead, and Dr. and Mrs.
Ronald T. Abercrombie. The assembly hall was tastefully decorated with holly and woodland
greens.
The programs were useful as
well as ornamental. The dance
cards were enclosed in neat black
leather wallets bearing the University Seal stamped thereupon in
gold. Two of these unique souvenirs were furnished to each couple. The hall was comfortably
filled with dancers, but was not
overcrowded, as has been the
case in former years. On the blackboard, situated at the east end of
the hall, the various football scores
of the past season were combined
in a cleverly executed design. On
account of the closeness of the
Christmas vacation, joy and mirth
were unbounded, and the entire assemblage seemed to be absolutely
carefree. The revelries lasted until
1.15 on Thursday morning, and, to
quote a familiar old chestnut, "A
good time was had by all."
• BIBLE CLASS NOTICE

The Wednesday Bible Class conducted by the "Y" will be discontinued until after the mid-year exams, when they will be resumed for
a period of two months.
During February and March,
therefore, the Bible classes will be
conducted and the "Y" is planning
for an interesting program.

VARSITY CLUB PRESIDENT RESIGNS

Dr. E. W. Bridgman, feeling the
,pressure of his professional duties,
has felt it necessary to resign as
president of the Varsity Club. He
had contemplated taking this step

Charles E.Skinner
HAT is insulation?—a necessary evil;—
the insulation engineer?—likewise a necW
esarsy evil;—such, too often, was the oldtime
formula. What wonder, with such a stigma,
that the vast majority of budding engineers of
bygone years side-stepped that branch of the
electrical art which was in such ill-repute.
Fortunately, a few far-visioned young men of
unusual caliber saw the great possibilities in this
field of endeavor and concentrated many of their
best years upon it. Foremost among these few
who have developed the insulation problem to a
leading position in the art,stands Charles E.Skinner, the head of the Research Department of the
Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Co.
For over thirty years, Mr. Skinner has been
delving into the whys and wherefores of the insulation problem, from extreme theoretical studies
to the most practical applications. His work
began at a time when there were no theories
worth while to consider, and when there were no
methods worth while to work with. It was not
only necessary to develop the insulation art from
the ground up, but all the tools of attack had to
be developed, and this latter means far more
than mere words can convey.

As an insulation engineer, Mr. Skinner has
always faced the necessity of utilizing a great
array of materials which are inferior in mechanical characteristics to those of the rest of the structure, such as papers,fibers, cottons,fabrics, mica,
varnishes, asphaltums,.oils, and various other unmechanical materials. Such materials are practically all affected, or destroyed, by undue heat.
Many of them are easily penetrated by moisture,
the arch enemy of insulation. Practically none of
these mateiials individually is ideal for the purpose desired, nor are they perfect in combination.
Consequently, the history of insulation is a story
of struggle, of frequent disappointment, and ofttimes mysterious failure.
It is now fully realized that the insulation
engineer is a vital and constructive factor in the
development of the electrical art. With the
great advances in recent years his high position
in the art is becoming more and more recognized, as the difficulties of his problems are
better realized. It may be said truly, that the
high position of the Westinghouse Company is
due, to a large extent, to the far reaching accomplishments of its insulation engineers, of
whom Mr. Skinner is the leading exponent.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 10, 1922
THE STUDENT ACTIVITIES COUNCIL'S REPORT

In this issue of the NEWS-LETTER
we are publishing the report of the
Student Activities Council for the
months of October, November and
December. Lack of space, unfortunately, prevents us from publishing a more detailed report, but from
all accounts the advantages of having such a council is unquestionable. The accounts are in excellent
shape and are accurately kept
through the centralized form of
bookkeeping adopted. Bills are
promptly paid, and a check is kept
on each activity, which prevents it
from exceeding its budget. The
'only activity in difficulty at present
is the Blue Jay, which had a deficit
of some three hundred and fifty
dollars from last year to meet this
fall. It is thought, however, that
with economy and hard work it
will be possible to make up this deficit by next year. The deficit last
February was over five hundred
dollars, two hundred of which was
made up in the last two issues of
last spring. Other activities which

THE SWIMMING TEAM

The Swimming Team needs $90,
to carry out its season, and it has
asked the students to support them
to that extent. Instead of asking
for contributions at a mass-meeting, however, it has planned a
dance to be given after its principal meet. We do not believe that
there is any danger of the students
failing to furnish the required support. The tickets are on sale now.
"Cotne early and avoid the rush !"

Approaches.
Lehigh
Pending.

ATHLETIC GOSSIP

Meet

Tickets have been placed on sale
for the swimming meet to be held
with Lehigh at the B. A. C. pool
on February 11. The contract for
this meet is being held up until
enough tickets are disposed of to
assure the payment of the guarantee to Lehigh. The future of the
swimming team depends upon the
disposal of these tickets. If Hopkins fails to meet Lehigh, who is
a member of the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming Association,
Hopkins will probably be dropped
ftom the league. The meet will
be followed by an informal dance.
Tickets 'are $1.50 per couple or $1
a person, and may be procured from
Andy, Landy & Co. or from members of the team.
The swimmers took their first
plunge of the season at the B. A. C.
pool last Wednesday. Only members of last year's team and Freshmen with previous experience were
told to report owing to limited facilities.

Men wishing to try for the team
will be given trials within the next
two weeks. The first meet is scheduled on January 21, at Swarthmore, and Manager Rowland and
Captain Buhrer, in charge of the
swimmers, will be forced to put the
men through daily practices in orcarried over a deficiency from last
year were the Dramatic Club and der to get them in condition at such
an early date. An unusually diffithe Debating Council.
We are glad to see that such a cult schedule has been arranged
large proportion of the students
have paid the fee, and are especially glad to hear that many who ai-e
not legally required to pay it have
done so in order to take advantage
ef the reduced rates. We only hope
thg the balance will pay as soon as
possible, not only for the advantages which they receive, but in order that the activities will receive
the unanimous support of the students.

The proposed football game with
the University of Maryland, according to unofficial information,
is about as far from a reality as it
was this time last year. The matter is at present being considered
by President Goodnow.
Lacrosse seems to be going
strong at all the big Eastern universities. Syracuse has made it a
major sport and Princeton has officially recognized it as a minor
sport. We are trying to get a game
with Princeton on June 3, and although the contracts are not signed
it looks as though we will have the
chance to entertain them on that
date.
Boxing apparently has gotten a
good hold at Hopkins. "Doc"
Rhodes is giving instruction to the
embryo battlers three evenings a
week at Homewood Field. Candidates for the team also get in some
good licks during vacant periods
in the students' room of the M. E.
Building.

and a well-balanced team is necessary in order to complete it with
satisfactory results. Captain Buhrer, Manager Rowland, Hall, Johnston, Morrell,

Hambleton

and

Coady of last year's team remain
as a nucleus.

Some of the new

candidates are showing up well and
are expected to make strong bids
for places on the team.

FIRST COTILLON OF YEAR HUGE
SUCCESS

The first cotillon of the collegiate year was held in the C. E. Hall
on Wednesday night, December 21,
1921. The dancing began at 9.00
P. M. to the jazzy strains of Lou
Fisher's orchestra. The chaperons
in attendance were Dr. and Airs.
John H. Latane, Dr. and Mrs. J.
B. Whitehead, and Dr. and Mrs.
Ronald T. Abercrombie. The assembly hall was tastefully decorated with holly and woodland
greens.
The programs were useful as
well as ornamental. The dance
cards were enclosed in neat black
leather wallets bearing the University Seal stamped thereupon in
gold. Two of these unique souvenirs were furnished to each couple. The hall was comfortably
filled with dancers, but was not
overcrowded, as has been the
case in former years. On the blackboard, situated at the east end of
the hall, the various football scores
of the past season were combined
in a cleverly executed design. On
account of the closeness of the
Christmas vacation, joy and mirth
were unbounded, and the entire assemblage seemed to be absolutely
carefree. The revelries lasted until
1.15 on Thursday morning, and, to
quote a familiar old chestnut, "A
good time was had by all."
• BIBLE CLASS NOTICE

The Wednesday Bible Class conducted by the "Y" will be discontinued until after the mid-year exams, when they will be resumed for
a period of two months.
During February and March,
therefore, the Bible classes will be
conducted and the "Y" is planning
for an interesting program.

Charles E.Skinner
HAT is insulation?—a necessary evil;—
the insulation engineer?—likewise a necW
esarsy evil;—such, too often, was the oldtime
formula. What wonder, with such a stigma,
that the vast majority of budding engineers of
bygone years side-stepped that branch of the
electrical art which was in such ill-repute.
Fortunately, a few far-visioned young men of
unusual caliber saw the great possibilities in this
field of endeavor and concentrated many of their
best years upon it. Foremost among these few
who have developed the insulation problem to a
leading position in the art,stands Charles E.Skinner, the head of the Research Department of the
Westinghouse Electric & Manufacturing Co.
For over thirty years, Mr. Skinner has been
delving into the whys and wherefores of the insulation problem, from extreme theoretical studies
to the most practical applications. His work
began at a time when there were no theories
worth while to consider, and when there were no
methods worth while to work with. It was not
only necessary to develop the insulation art from
the ground up, but all the tools of attack had to
be developed, and this latter means far more
than mere words can convey.

As an insulation engineer, Mr. Skinner has
always faced the necessity of utilizing a great
array of materials which are inferior in mechanical characteristics to those of the rest of the structure, such as papers,fibers, cottons,fabrics, mica,
varnishes, asphaltums,.oils, and various other unmechanical materials. Such materials are practically all affected, or destroyed, by undue heat.
Many of them are easily penetrated by moisture,
the arch enemy of insulation. Practically none of
these mateiials individually is ideal for the purpose desired, nor are they perfect in combination.
Consequently, the history of insulation is a story
of struggle, of frequent disappointment, and ofttimes mysterious failure.
It is now fully realized that the insulation
engineer is a vital and constructive factor in the
development of the electrical art. With the
great advances in recent years his high position
in the art is becoming more and more recognized, as the difficulties of his problems are
better realized. It may be said truly, that the
high position of the Westinghouse Company is
due, to a large extent, to the far reaching accomplishments of its insulation engineers, of
whom Mr. Skinner is the leading exponent.
